Award.AwardTitle: Renovation of a Shared Facility for Research and Research Training at a Science-Rich Liberal Arts Institution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5) to renovate the west wing of Stanley Hall, constructed in 1972 and shared by faculty in biology and chemistry. The renovation will affect about 5000 sq. ft. of laboratory space, which will be organized into "research neighborhoods". The theme of each research neighborhood will be dominated by the instrumentation it houses (analytical, biochemical, molecular, synthesis, and support). The renovation will provide house utilities that are currently inadequate or lacking, such as house air, vacuum, purified water and nitrogen gas, as well as improved storage, shelving and bench configuration.

The faculty in chemistry and biology have a strong track record of collaboration. The renovated and reorganized space is expected to foster and stimulate further collaboration, new research projects, student research training and recruitment of new faculty as well as competitiveness and productivity of current faculty.

Earlham College serves a student body that includes 12% underrepresented minorities as well as students from underserved and rural areas. These students will benefit from enhanced research training. In addition, the renovated facility will be used for outreach activities and to stimulate collaboration with local industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Earlham College’s grant was to update and reorganize our research facility in Stanley Hall to facilitate the type of science research that is currently being done.  To that end, we proposed reorganizing our space into research neighborhoods that would be organized by function, promote efficient/effective use of space, and foster even greater interactions between faculty and students. We also had a goal of modernizing the space by incorporating house utilities including compressed air, 18MOhm water, nitrogen and vacuum throughout the facility.  Receiving this NSF award inspired Earlham’s board of trustees to commit to raising additional funds for more extensive renovation and construction of a new teaching and research facility for physics, astronomy, and mathematics that will break ground in 2014.

 

The constructed research neighborhoods included Analytical (sample preparation and instrumentation), Biochemistry, Molecular and Physiological, Synthesis and Support. In total, the actual NSF renovation was 6275 sq.ft. compared to 4274 in the original grant, for a 47% increase in research neighborhood space. In addition to improving the facility in terms of collaborations and efficiency/effectiveness, the space’s energy efficiency will be approximately 50% of its pre-renovation usage.  The original grant called for a 14% Earlham match to account for the percentage of time that the research areas would be utilized for teaching purposes.  Because of the increased scope of work in the research neighborhoods, the total cost was $1,823,708.77, which was much larger than the original proposal. Therefore, the college match was $1,015,914.77 or 56% of the total cost, and the NSF grant ($807,794) was only 44% of the total cost.  This spending contributed significantly to the local economy as 76% of the direct cost dollars for the project went to Wayne County-based contractors.  If specialties with no Wayne County providers are factored out, then the local participation amounts to 97% of the total direct costs.  This local economic impact is consistent with the goals of the ARRA of which the NSF-ARI-R2 grant was a part.

 

The NSF-ARI-R2 grant that supported renovations to Stanley Hall has had a transformative effect on Earlham’s College’s science department.

 

The development of research neighborhoods and the inclusion of dependable, on-site molecular grade water, vacuums, air and gas at lab stations, has greatly ensured that students can efficiently conduct research from one central location. Further, faculty say there is confidence that the research being completed will have a successful endpoint and yield more publishable results for students, further increasing their marketability to employers or admissions counselors at post-graduate institutions.

 

Already, one in every 10 Earlhamites complete some form of doctoral study.  From 1992 to 2006, the College ranked 10th among 1,533 institutions of higher learning in the U.S. in the percentage of graduates who went on to receive Ph.D.’s in the biological sciences, according to a study by the Higher Education Data Consortium. Of those receiving Ph.D.’s in the life sciences in general, Earlham ranks 14th, according to the same study.

 

With state-of-the-art resources in the sciences and an increased emphasis on collaboration between science disciplines, Earlham faculty will also be better equipped to work alongside students and guide them in empirical research in a variety of scientific disciplines. About 85 percent of faculty report having worked collaboratively with students on meaningful research, which is a key element of our strategic plan.
